title: An Open Source tool helps a global community of professionals shift from traditional contacts and annual meetings to continuous interaction on the web
segmentation: The challenge we had from the end.
It was cool website with complex requirement features for these.
Groups of professionals in international organizations and multilateral bodies.
Also groups of people requiring a high level of confidentiality, but.
Being a very amorphous organization, this organization of Community really has no budget, depends on members contributions.
But being a success story nevertheless, it continues to grow and has been doing so since the late 80s.
The solution was quite obviously finding an open source tool that supports both languages easily and then crowdsourcing the translations from within the community based on the confidential.
The solution we found was called wiki.

Sticky that provides wiki content management system, and groupware software all bundled into one, and it is helped.
Turn the international Annual Meeting on Computer assisted translation terminology into an interactive hero.

Cat is available as you see in English.
In French, Spanish, Russian, Arabic, Chinese and German.
But what is it?
Started out as the joint Internet Agency meeting on computer assisted translation terminology, it was renamed some seven years six years ago to a more simple name.
It's a forum for debate, exchange of expertise and cooperation in this restricted community in the field of computer assisted terminology, translation, interpretation, etc.

And it works to establish a proprietary terminology and information repository common to all these participating organizations and to enhance exchanges where these language services with someone specificially needs.
Pull their information also about product things like that.

But the nice thing about an online site?
Collaborative site you see those in the yellow numbers there the growth has been extreme, but even since the meeting in April we've had continued continuing.
What's on this site?
It's full of pages of information and being wiki type pages, the information is being updated as people provide information as they discover new things.

There are files files could be anything from traditional glossary's information files on how to create a Moses in general, how to customize some things there aren't working groups, both mandated working groups with specific jobs and ad hoc working groups that basically develop their discussion.
To save money for the organizations involved, we now do online meeting registration and it's bilingual.
Could be multilingual there.
Online surveys and questionnaires and this interaction within the job community is also generated.

Summer.
Page views per day 76% last full year 69% since April.

It's a members only community and community is.

That's not bad for 1/2 months, including this slow summer doldrums.
Similar discussion forums.

Increase the number of threads actually being discussed.

The restricted access form is being used by these people more and more to discuss and argue through issues and is a lot clearer.
A lot more effective than the traditional email exchanges.

In some cases the working groups like to restrict certain access just to the members of that group as their own right.
They can do so.

Languages as well, because in addition to the original working groups on translation support tools and services, machine translation, standardization, and things like that.
WC at this year's meeting there was an Arabic translation tools created and obviously that site will be in Arabic as well as English and probably French, depending on what the users want.
And talking about generating activities beyond Jam Cat, we were recently informed about the Lynnport project.

The makers of this project have indicated the Jam cat helped them merge two very important projects, one based on the European Commission with other European involved and we have model aircraft is right here in the room.
The old multilingual autronic does.
Here project has been merged with the Container Project which was created by Alan Melby.
And some other people here in the room into the Lynnport language interoperability portfolio.
This is just taking off the first symposium on.
This will be taking place next week, hosted by the European Commission in Luxembourg and early next month.
There will be 1/2 day informational workshop in connection with localization world.
At the hosted by Gala in Santa Clara.

But what's really important for all of you is first of all, that all the results of this project are free and openly available, and this is something that, based on many of the talks here, could be very important.
Universal way to put everything that's needed for translation project into one electronic package.
But anyway, this is just showing you what.
And roll out of jam.
We're going to talk for a few minutes about features that support multilingualism by groups such as this, and I'm going to go into each one of these one by one would show you.
Pictures.
Ease of selecting and adding languages has implemented a jam cap.
We have a list of seven languages there.
You basically all you have to do is click the translate button and translated page into.
The languages.
That are there.
There's also the possibility of differentiating between human translation languages and machine translation languages.
On other sites.
One of the nice things is easy to see which language was last updated, which means updating.
There is no single source language.
The picture that you see on the right there is taken from an English page and it shows that that page is 94% up-to-date.

Incoming means that there are parts on a German, an Arabic on the Chinese version of that page that have been created more recently and where you need to do an update from those languages to English to make English 100% correct, and you basically just click this button to do that similarly.
Outgoing meaning that there are parts on the English page which need to update the German, Arabic, Russian and Spanish.
Review things on translate to translate from side by side.
You get color highlighting.
New, unchanged will replace text, so you have that in a lot of commercial tools.

It's based as much as they could on standards and it's available.
On the Internet as I said.
Source free charge.

Can view the history versions.
They can list them, review them side by side and if they want to they can rollback to any particular version.
Or you can see contributions by the individual author.
If you.

You can compare either 2 adjacent versions or in this case here.
CMT pairing versions that are quite a ways apart.
When you click the compare button, you actually see those parts that have been changed with the line.
The last line that hasn't been changed.
You see the changes and you then.
Can review those changes.
Necessary.
Action button and that rolls things back.

If you're using a tool where you let lots of people contribute, then a little bit like you might have on Wikipedia.
The thing is, you have to have the possibility of finding out who did and the possibility of reverting something that is quite correct or is decided by somebody else as not being what you want.
Last but not least, there is a possibility we're not using it very actively yet of staging approval.
This allows administrators to define updates of certain pages.
To be only draft mode, the user gets changed page, but the page is not publicly displayed until it's approved by somebody else who has the authority to approve this.

This feature was developed for taking for the Mozilla Foundation, who incidentally used this very software for their sumo support site for almost a decade before they switched late last year to their own developed software.
Which also shows you that it's a very powerful software now just a few words on the future of down Cat.
There's going to be more files, more pages forward, possibly more working groups and discussion forums.
We're going to be using features more.

We're looking into using other open source features, and one thing that I haven't got on the slide here of course, is we're looking into finding ways, and that's why I'm here of implementing standards that are available, and tools that support these.
One of the things that also happens and it was mentioned indirectly by one of the speakers earlier here, is we don't have enough translations.

We don't have all things translated into Spanish, for example, although we have a community of lots of people that speak Spanish, but they also by definition, because the translators also speak other languages and therefore they're happy reading the French or the English, and they're not willing to contribute as much.
So we need to activate more translators to do this, and one of the other things we're looking into.
He's trying to use.
Machine translation engines, but we can only use those that provide the security and confidentiality that Junkrat members required.

As some of you who were sitting here from some of the member organizations in the room know, there's certain translation engines that we can't use because that basically we don't know what happens with the data.
When it's used and possibly will have more unplanned positives such as.
Project.
Thank yous.

Thank you very very much and my whole body.
